key_points: The U.S. military conducted a drone strike in Afghanistan targeting an Islamic State member in retaliation for a deadly attack at Kabul airport.
The strike was in response to a suicide bombing claimed by IS that killed up to 169 Afghans and 13 American service members.
U.S. Central Command stated the drone strike occurred in Nangahar province, aiming to neutralize an IS member planning attacks against the U.S. in Kabul.
Navy Capt. William Urban confirmed the strike killed one individual and reported no civilian casualties.
The drone strike was authorized by President Joe Biden and ordered by Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin.
It is not confirmed if the targeted individual was directly involved in the Kabul airport suicide bombing.
The strike was executed using an MQ-9 Reaper drone to minimize potential civilian casualties.
This military action followed President Biden's vow to retaliate against the perpetrators of the Kabul attack.
The U.S. Embassy in Kabul issued a security alert advising U.S. citizens to avoid airport gates due to security threats.
President Biden was warned that another terror attack in Kabul is 'likely' as the U.S. approaches its deadline for military withdrawal.
spokespersons: Navy Capt. William Urban (Spokesman, U.S. Central Command)
Maj. Gen. Hank Taylor (Pentagon's Joint Staff)
